newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay shares close lower in erratic trade.
newsitem.headline: Bombay shares close lower in erratic trade.

text.p: Shares finished lower on Friday as players squared-up positions on the last day of weekly account at the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE), brokers said.
They said a possible increase in oil prices by the government over the weekend discouraged fresh demand.
"There was some stagnation," said Rasesh Maniar, dealer at brokerage Mukesh Babu Securities. "People know the (oil price) hike is coming and they're waiting."
The benchmark BSE index dropped 29.92 points, or 0.80 percent, to 3,700.86 off day's high of 3,742.35.
The steering committee of India's 15-party coalition government is scheduled to meet on Sunday to decide on ways to tackle a huge oil pool deficit.
Traders expect the government to raise prices of petroleum products, which India imports but sells at below world prices to domestic customers, to offset the deficit.
Activity was focussed on Tata Iron and Steel Company Ltd (TISCO) ahead of earnings announcement for the year ended March 31, 1997.
The company's board began a meeting at 1000 GMT to finalise the results.
Analysts expect flat-to-lower profits due to weak steel market conditions and higher costs.

Credit Rating Information Services India Ltd shares fell 3.75 rupees to 291.25 after the rating agency said its net profit rose marginally to 76.42 million rupees in 1996/97 (April-March) from 75.71 million a year ago.
